newsitem.title: JORDAN: Iraq demand behind Amman stocks healthy 1997 start.
newsitem.headline: Iraq demand behind Amman stocks healthy 1997 start.

text.p: Jordan's bourse was dragged down on its first 1997 trading day on Saturday by sell-offs in larger heavily-capitalised blue chips, triggered by start-of-year price corrections, dealers said.

However this was partially offset by the brighter performance of industrials that stand to benefit from exports to Iraq, which helped give the market a good start to the New Year with a healthy turnover of 995,263 dinars ($1.4 million).
The official Amman Financial Market 60-share index fell 1.21 percent to 151.61 points, attributed by dealers to falls in three large capitalised firms close to the five percent daily ceiling.
They are Arab Bank, Jordan Cement Factories and Jordan Phosphate Mines -- all heavily weighted in the official index based on market capitalisation.

Demand focussed mostly on drug, vegetable oils and detergent firms which have won export orders under Iraq's U.N. approved "oil-for food" deal, which should benefit 1997 half-year results, dealers said.

Investors' hopes of business opportunities in Iraq that could breathe new life into the Amman bourse were raised after recent orders exceeding $100 million were secured by leading Jordanian firms under the UN deal.

But the healthy activity was offset by price corrections in larger capitalised blue chips, whose closing levels had been artificially bolstered by stepped-up portfolio buying in the last week of 1996.
Portolios and institutions were inducing limited buying in selected shares to prop up closing prices to help reduce loss provisions for 1996 price falls that averaged around 12 percent.

"The start of 1997 witnessed a maximum drop in prices of these blue-chip shares that had been pushed up in the last day of 1996 trade in window dresssing deals for the sake of revaluation of portfolios and funds," said Nasser al-Amad, head of the brokerage firm United Financial Investments.
Among the busiest stocks were Unified Transport Company Jordan Petroleum Refinery and Arab Pharmaceutical Manufacturing -- all companies whose 1997 performance hinges on exports or links to Iraq.
They rose 0.10 dinar to 2.12 dinars, 0.03 dinar to 9.58 dinars and 0.12 dinar to 3.62 dinars respectively.
Arab Pharamaceutical Chemicals, a leading drug firm with substantial sales to Iraq, rose 5.26 percent to 1.40 dinars, in the day's highest rise in the bourse on Saturday.
The private Pearl Investable Index of the 45 best performing shares on the exchange shed 0.61 percent to 82.88 points from 83.39 points.
Rising shares outnumbered losers on Saturday by 29 to 16, with shares in four other firms trading but closing unchanged.
